DOC.brief_summary: Upper airway resistance during sleep can present with a range of symptoms from simple snoring (SS) through to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Pharyngeal narrowing or collapse leads to reduction or cessation in airflow during sleep, and is associated with loud snoring. The investigators hypothesized that regular singing exercises could strengthen pharyngeal muscles and/or increase their resting tone, and lead to an improvement of symptoms and thus quality of life in patients with all forms of snoring.
DOC.brief_title: Singing Exercises to Improve Symptoms of Snoring and Sleep Apnea
DOC.criteria: age 18 years old or over history of simple snoring or sleep apnoea with RDI 1040 severe sleep apnoea RDI >40 morbid obesity BMI > 40 unable to provide written informed consent
